author: McDy00
post_text: July 7, 2014 at 7:49 PM#1can someone give me a quick explanation of differences between those ?And, other great not much known command you guys using for macros?thanks

posts.author: McDy00
posts.post_text: July 7, 2014 at 7:49 PM#1can someone give me a quick explanation of differences between those ?And, other great not much known command you guys using for macros?thanks

posts.author: glad
posts.post_text: July 7, 2014 at 9:19 PM#2setvar versus setuservar only makes a difference if there is multiple usersuse "Add/SetVar" if the variable should be available (and the same) for all usersuse "Add/SetUserVar" if the variable should be individual per userSetVar deletes any old value and assigns a new value, while Addvar combines the old and the new value--SetVar $text="Andreas"SetVar $text="Glad"->$text=GladSetVar $text="Andreas"AddVar $text="Glad"->$text=AndreasGladSetVar $number=5SetVar $number=6->$number=6SetVar $number=5AddVar $number=6->$number=11

posts.author: McDy00
posts.post_text: July 7, 2014 at 9:42 PM#3Thank you very much !

posts.author: ivers
posts.post_text: July 9, 2014 at 8:04 AM#4I saw the syntax setvar $"something" used in a macro. Whats the difference between quotes or not in a variable name?

posts.author: glad
posts.post_text: July 9, 2014 at 10:29 AM#5the difference is the quotes ;-).embrace thenameof the variable in quotes when it is recalled, if thecontentneed to be embraced in quotes for correct interpretationSetvar $myname="Andreas Glad"Login $myname-> Login Andreas Glad ->[color=#FF0000]FAIL[/color]Login $"myname"-> Login "Andreas Glad" ->[color=#00FF00]PASS[/color]Setvar $mytarget="Executor 5"Go $mytarget->Go Executor 5 ->[color=#66CC33]PASS[/color]Go $"mytarget"->Go "Executor 5" ->[color=#FF0000]FAIL[/color]
